4.03. Second randomization
Let's have the same question, as before, but show the answer in-place:
Example: Connect countries with their respective capitals:
Countries: [[$o(a)::$n!()::Italy::Ethiopia::India::New Zealand::Germany]]
Capitals: [[$o(a)::$n!()::Rome::Addis Ababa::New Delhi::Wellington::Berlin]]
Or in list view:
[[$n(y)::$o(b, y)::Italy]]: [[$n!(z)::$o(b, z)::Rome]]
[[$n(y)::Ethiopia]]: [[$n(z)::Addis Ababa]]
[[$n(y)::India]]: [[$n(z)::New Delhi]]
[[$n(y)::New Zealand]]: [[$n(z)::Wellington]]
[[$n(y)::Germany]]: [[$n(z)::Berlin]]

[[$o!(a)::$o!(b)]] Look at the backside and be amazed how conveniently short this is.
"$order!(a)" defines order sharing after the second randomization. I'll try to explain it succinctly:
* While uncovering the frontside, you have two order-sharing sets, which are matched.
* However before you even get to the see the frontside, the second randomization will kick in, and mix up the countries again.
* Uncovering the backside will reveal a set which enables this in the second randomization set, which is why it the elements are automatically sorted.
The same can also work in reverse. You'd need a field that only appears on the front:
* This field contains the meta-element, to perform a second randomization of the capitals.
* The backside of the card misses this field. Thus the capitals are not randomized a second time, and still fit the countries!
